# 1. Using Vectors
# 1.a First 11 letters from LETTERS vector
first_11_letters <- LETTERS[1:11]
print(first_11_letters)

# 1.b Odd numbered letters
odd_letters <- LETTERS[seq(1, 26, 2)]
print(odd_letters)

# 1.c Vowels from LETTERS
vowels <- LETTERS[c(1, 5, 9, 15, 21)]
print(vowels)

# 1.d Last 5 lowercase letters from letters vector
last_5_letters <- letters[22:26]
print(last_5_letters)

# 1.e Letters between 15 and 24 in lowercase
subset_letters <- letters[15:24]
print(subset_letters)

# 2 Working with Temperature Data
# 2.a Character vector for cities
city <- c("Tuguegarao City", "Manila", "Iloilo City", "Tacloban", "Samal Island", "Davao City")
print(city)

# 2.b Temperature vector
temp <- c(42, 39, 34, 34, 30, 27)
print(temp)

# 2.c Creating a data frame
temp_data <- data.frame(City = city, Temperature = temp)
print(temp_data)

# 2.d Renaming columns (already done in Part 2c, this step is redundant)
# names(temp_data) <- c("City", "Temperature") 
# No need to rename the columns since they were already set when creating the data frame

# 2.e Print structure of data frame
str(temp_data)

# 2.f Content of row 3 and row 4
print(temp_data[3:4, ])

# 2.g City with the highest and lowest temperature
max_temp_city <- temp_data[which.max(temp_data$Temperature), "City"]
min_temp_city <- temp_data[which.min(temp_data$Temperature), "City"]

# Output the cities with the highest and lowest temperature
cat("City with the highest temperature:", max_temp_city, "\n")
cat("City with the lowest temperature:", min_temp_city, "\n")


# MATRICES
# 3.a Create a matrix with values from 1-8 and 11-14
matrix_data <- matrix(c(1:8, 11:14), nrow=3, ncol=4)
print(matrix_data)

# 3.b Multiply the matrix by 2
mult_matrix <- matrix_data * 2
print(mult_matrix)

# 3.c Content of row 2
print(matrix_data[2,])

# 3.d Display columns 3 and 4 in rows 1 and 2
print(matrix_data[1:2, 3:4])

# 3.e Display columns 2 and 3 in row 3
print(matrix_data[3, 2:3])

# 3.f Display column 4
print(matrix_data[, 4])

# 3.g Name rows and columns
rownames(mult_matrix) <- c("isa", "dalawa", "tatlo")
colnames(mult_matrix) <- c("uno", "dos", "tres", "quatro")
print(mult_matrix)

# 3.g(2) Reshape matrix to 6 rows and 2 columns
matrix_data <- matrix(c(1:8, 11:14), nrow=6, ncol=2)
print(matrix_data)

# ARRAYS
# 4.a Create a 3D array with repeated values
array_data <- array(rep(c(1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8, 9, 0, 3, 4, 5, 1), 2), dim=c(2, 4, 3))
print(array_data)

# 4.b Check array dimensions
print(dim(array_data))

# 4.c Name rows, columns, and dimensions
dimnames(array_data) <- list(letters[1:2], LETTERS[1:4], c("1st-Dimensional Array", "2nd-Dimensional Array", "3rd-Dimensional Array"))
print(array_data)
